com.google.code.gwt.database.client
Interface StatementCallback<T extends JavaScriptObject>

Type Parameters:
T - is the type which is eventually returned in the SQLResultSet at the onSuccess(SQLTransaction, SQLResultSet) call. You can use GenericRow as a safe default type.
public interface StatementCallback<T extends JavaScriptObject>

Provides the result of an executed SQL Statement.

All callback methods in this interface are called in the context of a SQL Transaction. This is important if you want to proceed your program after the SQL statements are executed: don't do that from this callback type, use the callback methods from SQLTransaction to proceed.

This interface specifies a type parameter to denote the type you expect to return in the resultset rows. A generic row type is GenericRow, which provides access to all row attributes dynamically. Use GenericRow like follows: 

 public class MyStmtCallback implements StatementCallback<GenericRow> {
     public void onSuccess(SQLTransaction tx, SQLResultSet<GenericRow> rs) {
         for (GenericRow row : rs.getRows()) {
             row.getString("name");  // returns the attribute 'name' from the row as a String
             row.getInt("age");  // returns the attribute 'age' from the row as an int
         }
     }
     public boolean onFailure(SQLTransaction transaction, SQLError error) {
         // You might want to do something here...
         return false;
     }
 }

See Also:
GenericRow, SQLTransaction, W3C Web Database - SQLStatementCallback, W3C Web Database - SQLStatementErrorCallback

Method Summary
 boolean onFailure(SQLTransaction transaction, SQLError error)
          This callback method is invoked if the SQL statement fails.
 void onSuccess(SQLTransaction transaction, SQLResultSet<T> resultSet)
          This callback method is invoked with the result of an executed SQL statement (be it SELECT, CREATE, UPDATE or anything else).
 

Method Detail

onSuccess

void onSuccess(SQLTransaction transaction,
               SQLResultSet<T> resultSet)
This callback method is invoked with the result of an executed SQL statement (be it SELECT, CREATE, UPDATE or anything else).

Note: DO NOT use this callback to proceed with your program (use TransactionCallback.onTransactionSuccess() for that). ONLY use this to process the resultSet, and/or execute additional SQL statements within the same transaction!

Parameters:
transaction - the transaction context of the callback, enabling additional SQLTransaction.executeSql(String, Object[]) calls within the same transaction
resultSet - the result of the statement

onFailure

boolean onFailure(SQLTransaction transaction,
                  SQLError error)
This callback method is invoked if the SQL statement fails.

Note: DO NOT use this callback to proceed with your program (use TransactionCallback.onTransactionFailure(SQLError) for that). ONLY use this to process the error, and/or execute additional SQL statements within the same transaction!

Parameters:
transaction - the transaction context of the callback, enabling additional SQLTransaction.executeSql(String, Object[]) calls within the same transaction
error - the SQL error causing the failure
Returns:
true if the specified transaction must be rolled-back, false otherwise. If true is returned, the TransactionCallback.onTransactionFailure(SQLError) callback will be invoked directly. Otherwise, the transaction will proceed to the next SQLTransaction.executeSql(String, Object[]) call, or invoke the TransactionCallback.onTransactionSuccess() callback if no SQL statements are left to execute.
